bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Lawrence [Walter L.] Reed, November 6, 1947

div1.p: Hench informs Lawrence Reed of his travels and activities, and requests that Lawrence Reed help him to identify the Army hospital room where Walter Reed died.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Lawrence [Walter L.] Reed, November 6, 1947
div1.opener:
Y. F.
November 6, 1947
General Walter Reed
2810 Thirty-Sixth Place, N.W.
Washington, D. C.
My dear General Reed:
div1.p:
Mrs. Hench and I are leaving here November 13 to go to Kentucky
where I will represent my alma mater at the inauguration of one of my
oldest friends as President of Center College. I will then go to Charlottes-
ville where I will give a talk on Monday, November 17 at the Medical School
on “Walter Reed and the Conquest of Yellow Fever”. I will then go to New
York for a council meeting of the International League against Rheumatism
and spend the weekend of November 22nd at Mercersburg visiting our son at
Mercersburg Academy, and will spend Monday and Tuesday, November 24 and 25
in Washington. I think Colonel Siler is hoping to have the forthcoming
meeting of the Board of Managers of the Walter Reed Memorial Association
in Washington on one of those days so that I may attend. I have appointments
with two or three men in the Pentagon Building but there is one thing that
I am most anxious to do while I am in Washington. Namely, visit the room
of your father where he passed away in the old Army hospital in Washington.

General Truby and I have been anxious to locate it the last time
I was in Washington, but the building, formerly a hospital building, is now
quarters for non-commissioned officers and we could not locate the room. I
understand that General Truby was able to locate it and that you visited the
room with him.

The reasons we are anxious to identify the room are multiple.
First of all, for sentimental reasons. Secondly, for historical reasons.
General Kean and I (at least he was kind enough to let on that he agreed)
agreed that at the very least a small modest marker should be placed in
the appropriate place outside or inside the building. I realize that interest
in such a room might to some seem morbid but where great men lived and died
is always of concern to historians. Would it be possible for you to come with
me and point this room out to me.

I enclose a stamped air mail envelope for reply. If it is not
possible for you to go with me this time we might be able to go some other
time.
div1.closer:
Always sincerely, Philip S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
